item.title: Al Qaeda Denies U.S. Strike Killed Key Jihadist in Libya
item.description: It was the second such statement denying that Mokhtar Belmokhtar, the man behind the 2013 seizure of an Algerian gas plant that left 38 hostages dead, had been killed.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI

item.title: New Jersey Man Is Charged With Planning to Aid ISIS
item.description: The arrest of Samuel Rahamin Topaz, of Fort Lee, was the fourth targeting a ring of young men suspected of sympathizing with the terrorist group.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: BENJAMIN MUELLER

item.title: Many Ask, Why Not Call Church Shooting Terrorism?
item.description: Civil rights activists see hypocrisy in how law enforcement and the news media describe attacks by whites as compared with similar attacks by blacks or Muslim Americans.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: Bahrain: Explosives Seized, Police Say
item.description: The methods used to assemble the explosives bore “clear similarities” to those of what he called proxy groups of Iran’s Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Thailand: First MERS Case Confirmed
item.description: Thailand on Thursday confirmed its first known case of the deadly Middle East respiratory syndrome: a 75-year-old man who recently traveled from Oman.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Niger: 40 Killed in Cross-Border Attacks
item.description: Militants from the Nigeria-based Islamic extremist group Boko Haram crossed the border into Niger, setting homes ablaze and killing at least 40 people.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: In the Footsteps of Popes Seeking Worldly Change
item.description: Industrialists, politicians and critics are fuming, contending that the pope should stick to religion and stop meddling in matters in which he has no competence.
item.dc:creator: LAURIE GOODSTEIN
item.media:description: Pope Francis issued a paper on combating climate change.

item.title: Anti-Immigrant Party Gains in Denmark Elections
item.description: The far-right Danish People’s Party emerged in second place overall, raising questions about the role it could play in a new government.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: The leader of the Liberal Party, Lars Lokke Rasmussen, is expected to become the next premier.

item.title: Championing Environment, Francis Takes Aim at Global Capitalism
item.description: The encyclical by Pope Francis could give both sides in the global warming debate ammunition over how to address climate change.
item.dc:creator: CORAL DAVENPORT
item.media:description: A boy pulled recyclable items from a garbage dump in Gauhati, India. That nation has refused to enact climate change policies without pledges of aid from wealthy countries.

item.title: World Briefing: Tunisia: Gunmen Free Officials in Libya
item.description: Ten consular officials kidnapped from the Tunisian Consulate in Libya were released overnight after days of negotiations.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Peter J. Li on the Clash Over Eating Dogs in China
item.description: Peter J. Li, a China policy adviser with Humane Society International, discusses the conflict between those who defend dog eating as a Chinese cultural tradition and those who view dogs as cherished companions.
item.dc:creator: SHAOJIE HUANG
item.media:description: Dog meat for sale at a market in Yulin on Wednesday, ahead of this weekend's celebration of the summer solstice with banquets of dog meat and lychees.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Reactions to the Defeat of the Hong Kong Election Plan
item.description: Pro-democracy campaigners cheered its failure, while supporters of the Beijing-backed proposal vowed to use the defeat to campaign against pan-democratic lawmakers.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Pro-democracy demonstrators celebrating outside the Legislative Council in Hong Kong on Thursday after it rejected a Beijing-vetted proposal on electing the city’s top official.

item.title: Cuba Offers Its Citizens Better Access to Internet
item.description: Cuba, one of the Western Hemisphere’s least-wired countries, is poised to expand access to the Internet by introducing some three dozen Wi-Fi hot spots around the island and reducing the steep fees.
item.dc:creator: VICTORIA BURNETT

item.title: Thione Ballago Seck’s Arrest at Odds With Religious Image in Senegal
item.description: The singer’s fans express disappointment that he is entangled in a forgery scandal in Dakar.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:credit: Jack Vartoogian for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senegalese music star Thione Ballago Seck in a 2003 photo. The police in Dakar accused Mr. Seck of a role in a counterfeit currency ring. forgery after a raid on his home.

item.title: Senate Passes, Then Blocks, Military Bill
item.description: The lawmakers’ action was seen as the first battle in a spending fight that could end in a government shutdown this fall.
item.dc:creator: JENNIFER STEINHAUER
item.media:description: Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, right, and Senator John McCain talked to reporters on Thursday after the vote on the National Defense Authorization Act.

item.title: Houses of Parliament Are Crumbling, Report Finds, and There Is No Quick Fix
item.description: With renovation expected to take years and cost $6.2 billion or more, some even suggest finding another home away from London.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Scaffolding surrounding part of the Houses of Parliament in London. A new report says that repairs could take as long as 30 years and cost more than $11 billion.

item.title: ISIS-Imposed Fuel Embargo Threatens Syria’s Medical Centers
item.description: The Islamic State is preventing fuel from reaching rebel-held parts of northern Syria, as the Assad government targets medical facilities, activists and aid workers say.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Hong Kong Legislature Rejects Beijing-Backed Election Plan
item.description: In the end, it was the pro-democracy camp that killed a proposal for direct election of the city’s top leader, citing Beijing’s limits on who could be a candidate.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE and ALAN WONG
item.media:description: Lawmakers who supported the Beijing-backed election proposal in Hong Kong after the legislation was voted down on Thursday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Rare Direct Appeal to Xi Jinping Appears, Then Disappears, Online
item.description: An online video, quickly deleted from Chinese outlets, shows a woman being subdued by bystanders after she called out to President Xi Jinping’s motorcade in the southwestern province of Guizhou.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK BOEHLER

item.title: Former Israeli Envoy Weighs In on Frayed Relations Between Obama and Netanyahu
item.description: Israeli apologies were in order after the former envoy, Michael B. Oren, wrote about President Obama’s dealings with Israel and Benjamin Netanyahu.
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Michael B. Oren, the former Israeli ambassador to the United States.
